cot.content:
To solve the problem, Please think and reason step by step, then answer.
question:
Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?
        
Generation Format:
Reasoning process:
Answer:

Reasoning process:
The quote "I married beneath me, all women do" is attributed to Lady Nancy Astor, who was a prominent British politician and the first woman to take her seat in the House of Commons. She was known for her outspoken views and her role in politics during the early 20th century. The quote reflects her perspective on marriage and societal norms regarding women and their choices. 

Answer:
Lady Nancy Astor

anchoring.content:
You are a cognitive scientist, to answer the following question:
Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?
I will provide you with several retrieved passages:
Passages:
['Queen Sophie Amalie was described as ambitious and was well known to participate in state affairs, with the blessing of her husband, and influence policy as his adviser. Her great influence upon her husband was widely known already before he became king: before Frederick had succeeded to the throne, a satire circulated in which this was caricatured in the form of a mock question: "Can a husband make any decisions whatever without the consent of his wife? Signed Duke Frederick." \n', 'In a 2008 interview for the biography book "La Reina muy cerca" (The Queen Up Close) by Spanish journalist and writer Pilar Urbano, Queen Sofía of Spain sparked controversy by voicing her disapproval of LGBT pride. This was in addition to overstepping her official duties as a member of the Royal Family by censuring the Spanish Law on Marriage in how it names same-sex unions as "matrimonio" (marriage). Without using the slogan "Straight Pride", Queen Sofía was directly quoted as saying that if heterosexuals were to take the streets as the LGBT community does for Gay Pride parades, that the former collective would bring Madrid to a standstill.\n', 'Saint Anne was the patron saint of unmarried women, particularly because of the legend that she had been married three times.\n', 'Friedrich Adolph Riedesel was a member of the line of Riedesel zu Eisenbach, and like all his male cousins had the title of "Freiherr" or Baron. He was not "the Baron" or "von Riedesel." Upon their marriage Frederika gained the title of "Freifrau" or Baroness Riedesel zu Eisenbach. She was described as looking more like an unmarried school girl than a married woman. She would grow into a red-haired baroness, "full in figure and possessing no small share of beauty." In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".\n', 'During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.\n', 'Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. The allegation of bisexuality was never made known to him, but it is notable that Frederick later had a happy marriage, with no hint of either bisexuality (granted, of course, that as a bisexual man, he would have no problem in having sexual relations with a woman) or violence, with Princess Charlotte of Great Britain.\n', 'When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington\'s one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.\n', 'Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I\'d rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"\n', 'Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix\'s influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.\n', 'One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. These I count as nothing, compared with the happiness you have it in your power to bestow."\n']

Task Description:
Please extract content that may be unfamiliar to the model from these passages, 
which can provide the model with relevant background and unknown knowledge and concepts, 
helping it better understand the question. and analyze the role of these contents.

To address the question regarding the female politician and aristocrat who said, "I married beneath me, all women do," we can analyze the provided passages for relevant context and background information that may enhance understanding.

### Relevant Content and Analysis:

1. **Queen Sophie Amalie**:
   - The passage describes Queen Sophie Amalie as an ambitious figure who participated in state affairs and influenced policy as an adviser to her husband. This context highlights the role of women in political spheres, particularly in aristocratic settings, where their influence could extend beyond traditional domestic roles. This may relate to the quote in question, as it suggests a recognition of the complexities of marriage and social status among women.

2. **Queen Sofía of Spain**:
   - This passage mentions Queen Sofía's controversial remarks regarding LGBT pride and her role within the Royal Family. While not directly related to the quote, it illustrates the challenges and public scrutiny faced by female royals and politicians, which can inform the understanding of societal expectations placed on women, particularly in aristocratic contexts.

3. **Friedrich Adolph Riedesel and Frederika**:
   - The description of Frederika gaining the title of "Freifrau" (Baroness) upon marriage and her role as a mother and wife provides insight into the expectations of women in aristocratic families. The mention of her husband’s military promotion and her title reflects the intertwining of gender roles and social status, which may relate to the sentiment expressed in the quote about marrying beneath one's status.

4. **Brigitte Frank**:
   - Brigitte Frank's statement about preferring widowhood over divorce from a Reichsminister underscores the societal pressures and expectations on women to maintain their status and relationships, even in unhappy marriages. This aligns with the quote's theme of women navigating social hierarchies through marriage.

5. **Countess and Groom**:
   - The anecdote about the Countess expressing her love for a groom of lower status illustrates the emotional complexities of marrying across social classes. The Countess's rejection of societal norms in favor of personal happiness resonates with the quote's implication that women often find themselves in positions where they must navigate societal expectations regarding marriage.

### Conclusion:
The passages collectively provide a backdrop of the historical and social context in which women, particularly those of aristocratic status, operated. They reveal the complexities of marriage, social status, and the influence of women in political and personal realms. The quote about marrying beneath oneself can be understood as a reflection of the societal norms and pressures that women faced, often leading them to prioritize personal happiness over societal expectations. This context enriches the understanding of the quote and the broader implications of women's roles in society. 

The specific attribution of the quote to a particular female politician or aristocrat is not directly found in the passages, but the themes explored can guide further research into notable figures who may have expressed similar sentiments.

Lady Nancy Astor

The quote "I married beneath me, all women do" is attributed to **Lady Nancy Astor**, the first woman to sit as a Member of Parliament in the British House of Commons. This statement reflects her views on marriage and societal expectations regarding gender and class.

### Analysis of the Passages

1. **Historical Context of Female Aristocrats**:
   - The passages provide examples of various female figures from history, such as Queen Sophie Amalie and Princess Dorothea Lieven, who navigated their roles in society, often influenced by their marriages and social status. This context highlights the complexities of female agency within patriarchal structures.

2. **Marriage and Social Status**:
   - The quote from Lady Astor speaks to the common sentiment among women of her time regarding marriage dynamics. The passages illustrate how women, regardless of their aristocratic status, often felt constrained by societal expectations and norms surrounding marriage. For instance, the Countess in one passage expresses her love for a man of lower status, emphasizing the tension between personal desire and societal rank.

3. **Influence of Women in Politics**:
   - The mention of Queen Sophie Amalie's influence on her husband’s decisions and policies underscores the significant, albeit often indirect, role women played in political affairs. This aligns with Lady Astor's position as a trailblazer for women in politics, suggesting that while women may have married "beneath" them in terms of social hierarchy, they often wielded considerable influence behind the scenes.

4. **Cultural Perceptions of Women**:
   - The passages reflect the cultural perceptions of women during different historical periods, such as the distinction between titles like "mademoiselle" and "madame" in France, which indicates the societal hierarchy and the limited recognition of married women compared to their male counterparts.

### Consolidation of Knowledge

The quote from Lady Astor encapsulates a broader theme of women's experiences in marriage and society, particularly in relation to class and power dynamics. The passages illustrate that:

- **Marriage as a Social Contract**: Women often had to navigate the complexities of marrying men of different social standings, which could affect their status and influence.
- **Historical Precedents**: The experiences of historical figures like Queen Sophie Amalie and the Countess reflect ongoing struggles for agency and recognition within a male-dominated society.
- **Political Influence**: Women, even when perceived as having "married beneath" their status, often played crucial roles in shaping political landscapes through their relationships and social networks.

### Conclusion

Understanding Lady Astor's quote in conjunction with the historical context provided by the passages deepens the comprehension of women's roles in society, particularly in relation to marriage, influence, and the ongoing struggle for recognition and power. This analysis highlights the complexities of gender dynamics throughout history and the ways in which women have navigated societal expectations.

   - Lady Astor's role as a pioneering female politician came during a time when women were just beginning to gain a foothold in public life. This reflects a broader trend where women, despite societal limitations, played crucial roles in shaping political landscapes. 5. **Broader Implications of the Quote**:

', 'When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington's one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.
', 'Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I'd rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"
', 'Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix's influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.
', 'One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. These I count as nothing, compared with the happiness you have it in your power to bestow."
']

To answer the following question:
Which female politician and aristocrat said ‘I married beneath me, all women do’?

Passages:
['Queen Sophie Amalie was described as ambitious and was well known to participate in state affairs, with the blessing of her husband, and influence policy as his adviser. Her great influence upon her husband was widely known already before he became king: before Frederick had succeeded to the throne, a satire circulated in which this was caricatured in the form of a mock question: "Can a husband make any decisions whatever without the consent of his wife? Signed Duke Frederick." \n', 'In a 2008 interview for the biography book "La Reina muy cerca" (The Queen Up Close) by Spanish journalist and writer Pilar Urbano, Queen Sofía of Spain sparked controversy by voicing her disapproval of LGBT pride. This was in addition to overstepping her official duties as a member of the Royal Family by censuring the Spanish Law on Marriage in how it names same-sex unions as "matrimonio" (marriage). Without using the slogan "Straight Pride", Queen Sofía was directly quoted as saying that if heterosexuals were to take the streets as the LGBT community does for Gay Pride parades, that the former collective would bring Madrid to a standstill.\n', 'Saint Anne was the patron saint of unmarried women, particularly because of the legend that she had been married three times.\n', 'Friedrich Adolph Riedesel was a member of the line of Riedesel zu Eisenbach, and like all his male cousins had the title of "Freiherr" or Baron. He was not "the Baron" or "von Riedesel." Upon their marriage Frederika gained the title of "Freifrau" or Baroness Riedesel zu Eisenbach. She was described as looking more like an unmarried school girl than a married woman. She would grow into a red-haired baroness, "full in figure and possessing no small share of beauty." In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".\n', 'During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.\n', 'Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. The allegation of bisexuality was never made known to him, but it is notable that Frederick later had a happy marriage, with no hint of either bisexuality (granted, of course, that as a bisexual man, he would have no problem in having sexual relations with a woman) or violence, with Princess Charlotte of Great Britain.\n', 'When remarking in her diaries on other women who shared their affections with great men of the day, Arbuthnot displayed a sharp, ironic wit. Of Wellington\'s one-time mistress Princess Dorothea Lieven, wife to the Imperial Russian ambassador to London from 1812 to 1834, she wrote "It is curious that the loves and intrigues of a femme galante should have such influence over the affairs of Europe." Arbuthnot obviously failed to realise she was regarded by some in London society as a "femme galante" in a similar situation herself.\n', 'Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. When Frank sought a divorce in 1942, Brigitte gave everything to save their marriage in order to remain the "First Lady in the General Government". One of her most famous comments was "I\'d rather be widowed than divorced from a Reichsminister!" Frank answered: "So you are my deadly enemy!"\n', 'Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix\'s influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court. (As explained by the Roman historian Tacitus, Felix and his brother Marcus Antonius Pallas were descended from the Greek kings of Arcadia.) At the time of her first marriage, Drusilla was the only daughter of a king of a former kingdom, which may explain her title; the title may also reveal the identity of her second husband.\n', 'One day it is said: the Countess summoned the groom to her presence, and, to his amazement and embarrassment, told him that she had long grown to love him, and that she asked nothing better of life than to become his wife. Overcome with surprise and confusion, Forbes protested: "But my lady, think of the difference between us. You are one of the greatest ladies in the land, and I am no better than the earth you tread on." "You must not say that", the Countess replied. "You are more to me than rank or riches. passages:
Queen Sophie Amalie was described as ambitious and was well known to participate in state affairs, with the blessing of her husband, and influence policy as his adviser. Her great influence upon her husband was widely known already before he became king: before Frederick had succeeded to the throne, a satire circulated in which this was caricatured in the form of a mock question: "Can a husband make any decisions whatever without the consent of his wife? Signed Duke Frederick."

This was in addition to overstepping her official duties as a member of the Royal Family by censuring the Spanish Law on Marriage in how it names same-sex unions as "matrimonio" (marriage). She would grow into a red-haired baroness, "full in figure and possessing no small share of beauty." In the following years, the Riedesels had two daughters, Gustava and Frederica, and Frederika was pregnant with a third, Carolina, in 1776 when Brunswick signed a treaty to support Great Britain in the suppression of the rebellion in their American colonies. Friedrich was promoted to General and named commander of the Brunswick army, and he referred to Frederika as "Mrs. General".
During the "Ancien Régime", a female commoner was always addressed as "mademoiselle", even when married, "madame" being limited to women of the high nobility, even if they were not married. This practice ceased after the French Revolution.
Before he left, Frederick made it known through Sophie to the Empress that he regarded his wife to be as of "poor character" as she behaved with too much informality with servant-lads, grooms and aides, and that the "violence" she accused him of was only his insistence that she should behave with adequate reserve towards them, in keeping with what was regarded as suitable for a woman of her high rank. Brigitte Frank had a reputation for having a more dominant personality than her husband: after 1939 she called herself "a queen of Poland" (""Königin von Polen""). The marriage was unhappy and became colder from year to year. Drusilla held the Latin honorary title of "Regina". The Roman historian Suetonius only uses the word "Regina" to describe a queen regnant or a queen consort. According to Suetonius, she is one of the three queens whom Felix married. Her title may have been purely honorary; possibly it reveals Felix's influence, the high position to which Claudius had appointed him, and his quasi-royal status in the imperial court.
